nodes.text: Policymaking and national statistics should report both the ensemble-average (GDP per capita) growth rate and the time-average (DDP per capita) growth rate because they capture different aspects of economic growth and together give a more complete picture
When incomes follow random multiplicative growth, the ensemble-average growth rate exceeds the time-average growth rate
The ensemble-average growth rate corresponds to GDP per capita growth and is approximately an income-weighted (plutocratic) average of individual growth rates
The time-average growth rate corresponds to DDP per capita growth, equals the average of individual log-growth rates, and is the growth rate of the geometric mean income (democratic measure)

The difference between ensemble-average and time-average growth rates defines a natural inequality measure, the ergodicity gap, which under multiplicative dynamics equals the mean logarithmic deviation (MLD, second Theil index)

The time-average growth rate and the ergodicity gap depend only on initial and terminal income distributions and are independent of income rank mobility, allowing estimation from cross-sectional quantile data rather than panel data

Mathematical argument using a logarithmic ergodicity transformation: taking logs of multiplicative updates yields additive stationary increments so the growth rate of ln(income) is ergodic and individual long-run growth equals the expectation of short-term log-growth
Jensen's inequality (log concavity) implies ln(mean income) >= mean(ln income), yielding nonnegative difference g_ensemble - g_time and equality only under perfect equality
For small changes, ensemble-average growth rate can be approximated as sum over i of wi gi with weights wi proportional to individual incomes xi, formalizing the plutocratic interpretation
Time-average growth rate can be estimated as change in average log income: g_time = Delta⟨ln x⟩/Delta t and DDP per capita y(t)=exp(⟨ln x(t)⟩)
Practical estimation of g_time uses percentiles/quantile averages of income to compute average log-income changes when panel data are unavailable

Under geometric Brownian motion (GBM) model: ensemble growth g_ensemble = mu, time-average growth g_time = mu - sigma^2/2, and ergodicity gap grows at rate sigma^2/2, so inequality (MLD) increases unboundedly

Empirical finding: in US data since about 1980 GDP per capita grew substantially faster than DDP per capita (ensemble > time), whereas in France the two growth rates remained closer over the last fifty years

Observed behavior: the ergodicity gap (MLD) and top 10% income share evolve similarly and increased in the United States while remaining more stable in France, consistent with divergence between ensemble and time growth in the US

Conclusion: relying only on GDP per capita risks a political disconnect where aggregate indicators show strong growth while typical individual experience (DDP per capita) is weaker; reporting all three metrics (GDP per capita, DDP per capita, ergodicity gap/MLD) would better inform policy
Limitation: DDP per capita (geometric mean) is sensitive to measurement of low incomes, so truncation of bottom incomes affects quantitative estimates and requires care in empirical implementation
